citations.narrative:
The animal inventory at the time of inspection July 1st, 2025, was 1240 total covered animals. This number exceeds the
maximum number of 1150 animals allowed under the current license.
The USDA license authorizes a specific number of animals to ensure the facility can provide care for that number of
animals.
Licensee must obtain a new license before any change resulting in more than the authorized number of animals on hand
at any single point in time during the period of licensure. The licensee must maintain no more than the maximum number
of animals that their USDA license allows.
To be corrected: September 1, 2025.

On June 23, 2025, a 6-year-old adult male elk (G25) escaped from its enclosure by breaking through the enclosure fence.
The elk was seen running outside the fence along a highway. The elk was returned inside the fence but as a result
suffered injuries which lead to it being euthanized by direction of the Attending Veterinarian.
Indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be constructed of such material and of such strength as appropriate for the
animals involved and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals. A
failure in this could lead to injury or escape from the facility. Escaped animals have the potential for increased stress,
discomfort, developing health issues, or being killed. Correct by ensuring that all housing facilities are constructed of such
material and of such strength as appropriate for the animals involved and maintained in good repair to protect the animals
and prevent future escape.
Corrected at time of inspection: July 1st, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.1(b)(2)(i) 
   
Requirements and application 
The animal inventory at the time of inspection July 1st, 2025, was 1240 total covered animals. This number exceeds the 
maximum number of 1150 animals allowed under the current license. 
The USDA license authorizes a specific number of animals to ensure the facility can provide care for that number of 
animals. 
Licensee must obtain a new license before any change resulting in more than the authorized number of animals on hand 
at any single point in time during the period of licensure. The licensee must maintain no more than the maximum number 
of animals that their USDA license allows. 
To be corrected: September 1, 2025. 
3.125(a)  Critical
   
Facilities, general. 
On June 23, 2025, a 6-year-old adult male elk (G25) escaped from its enclosure by breaking through the enclosure fence. 
The elk was seen running outside the fence along a highway. The elk was returned inside the fence but as a result 
suffered injuries which lead to it being euthanized by direction of the Attending Veterinarian.  
Indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be constructed of such material and of such strength as appropriate for the 
animals involved and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals. A 
failure in this could lead to injury or escape from the facility. Escaped animals have the potential for increased stress, 
discomfort, developing health issues, or being killed. Correct by ensuring that all housing facilities are constructed of such 
material and of such strength as appropriate for the animals involved and maintained in good repair to protect the animals 
and prevent future escape. 
Corrected at time of inspection: July 1st, 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
